In this video, we'll explore the benefits of continuous integration and show you a real-world example of using GitHub Actions and Google Test for C/C++ projects.

localized.description:
In this tutorial, we'll show you how to create an augmented reality application using a webcam, OpenCV, ESP32, and FreeRTOS. We're going to use the webcam to capture videos, OpenCV to process the videos and detect fingers, ESP32 to control the lights, and FreeRTOS to manage the system. We will also use a temperature sensor to retrieve temperature and pressure values.

First, let's start with setting up the hardware. We are going to connect the webcam to the ESP32 and start it up. Next, we'll connect the temperature sensor to the ESP32 and set it up to measure temperature and pressure.

Next, we are going to move on to the software part. We are going to use OpenCV to process the videos captured by the webcam and to detect fingers in the video stream. We're going to use the ESP32 to control the lights and adjust their brightness and color based on finger detection. We are also going to use FreeRTOS to manage the system and ensure that everything is working properly.

Once we set up the system, we'll test it and show you how it works. We will use the webcam to capture videos, the temperature sensor to retrieve temperature and pressure values, OpenCV to process the videos and detect hands, and the ESP32 to control the lights.

localized.description:
In this video, we explore creating artificial intelligence that can recognize presidents' faces using deep learning and convolutional neural networks. We start by explaining the various steps in the process, from collecting data to creating a user-friendly web application with Streamlit.

First, we approach data collection by bringing together a vast set of images of different presidents from a variety of sources. We also discuss the challenges of manually tagging images to form our facial recognition model.

Next, we explore data augmentation techniques to diversify our training set. Increasing data involves transformations such as rotating, cropping, and scaling images to improve the generalization capacity of our model.

We then move on to creating and training our convolutional neural network model. We explain the different layers of the model, such as the convolutional, pooling, and fully connected layers, and their role in learning the characteristics of presidential faces.

Once the model is trained, we move on to creating an interactive web application using Streamlit. This application will allow users to upload an image containing the face of a president and instantly get a prediction about his identity using our face recognition model.

By following this video, you will gain a thorough understanding of the process of creating a facial recognition AI based on convolutional neural networks. You will be able to replicate these steps for other image recognition applications.
